title: 103_hr1312
content: The Act is titled the "Local Exchange Infrastructure Modernization Act of 1993". It includes findings related to the act. The Congress finds that a high-quality public switched network will promote universal service, availability of advanced capabilities, public health, safety, national defense, economic development, and international competitiveness. The Congress emphasizes the importance of a seamless, nationwide communications infrastructure to enhance the quality of life for all Americans. This includes sharing infrastructure and functionality among local exchange carriers, coordinated network planning, and development of standards for interconnection. The Congress emphasizes the importance of a seamless, nationwide communications infrastructure to enhance the quality of life for all Americans. This involves local exchange carriers providing access to competitor carriers, information service providers, and others to create an interoperable national telecommunications network. It is in the public interest to promote the development of the public switched network by local exchange carriers due to their universal service obligations and the enhancement of services provided by all carriers and network users. Local exchange carriers must provide public switched network services that are regulated for rates, terms, and conditions, offer network access to competitors on fair terms, and act as suppliers of last resort in their service areas. Amendments to the Communications Act of 1934. Amendment to Section 1 of the Communications Act of 1934 includes preserving universal service, achieving universal availability of advanced network capabilities, maintaining high quality standards, and ensuring communication for public health, safety, defense, education, national security, and emergency preparedness. Amendments to the Communications Act of 1934 focus on updating regulations related to telecommunications services, including changes to specific sections such as 2(b) and 3. These changes aim to define terms like 'local exchange carrier' and ensure compliance with government oversight for access services and telephone exchange. The amendments to the Communications Act of 1934 focus on updating regulations related to telecommunications services, including defining terms like 'local exchange carrier' and ensuring compliance with government oversight for access services and telephone exchange. The amendments also include requirements related to equal access and numbering resources for telephone exchange service. The Commission must prescribe regulations within 180 days for joint network planning among local exchange carriers and standards for interconnection. Additionally, infrastructure sharing arrangements between local exchange carriers are addressed. The Commission must prescribe regulations within 180 days for sharing public switched network infrastructure among local exchange carriers lacking economies of scale or scope. The regulations aim to promote economically efficient decision-making and do not mandate any carrier to make any specific actions. The regulations aim to promote economically efficient decision-making among local exchange carriers, allowing joint ownership and operation of network infrastructure. Fair and reasonable terms must be ensured when sharing infrastructure, without deeming carriers as common carriers for hire. The regulations aim to establish fair terms and conditions for business arrangements between local exchange carriers, promoting cooperation and ensuring regulatory rights are determined according to prescribed regulations. The Act does not enact any new economic support for telephone exchange service or prohibit new support mechanisms for other services. SEC. 230 allows local exchange carriers to transport or process signaling and information for another carrier in nearby areas. SEC. 231 clarifies that state regulations on intrastate communication service remain unaffected. SEC. 4 grants antitrust immunity to local exchange carriers. Antitrust laws do not apply to actions taken by local exchange carriers under specific sections of the Communications Act of 1934, including lobbying and communication with other carriers. Definitions for "Federal antitrust laws" are provided. The term "State antitrust laws" refers to laws enacted by States or territories within the United States or their political subdivisions that are similar to Federal antitrust laws such as the Sherman Act, Clayton Act, Robinson-Patman Act, and Federal Trade Commission Act. These laws aim to regulate contracts, combinations, conspiracies in restraint of trade, and monopolistic practices. State antitrust laws are similar to Federal Acts, regulating contracts, combinations, conspiracies in restraint of trade, and monopolistic practices.
